sp.l: Say sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: One whom I dare presume, next to your children,
You tendered above life.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Heaven will not suffer me utterly to be lost.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: For he should have been
Your son-in-law, miraculously saved,
When Surgery gave him over.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O, may you live
To win many souls to heaven, worthy sir,
That your crown may be the greater. Why my son
made me believe he stole into his chamber,
And ended that which Ercole began
By a deadly stab in his heart.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Alas, she mistakes,
It is Contarino she wishes living; but I must fasten
On her last words, for my own safety.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where, O where shall I meet this comfort?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Here in the vowed comfort of your daughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
O I am dead again, instead of the man, you present
me the grave swallowed him.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Collect yourself, good Lady,
Would you behold brave Contarino living?
There cannot be a nobler Chronicle
Of his good than myself: if you would view him dead,
I will present him to you bleeding fresh,
In my penitency.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, you do only live,
To redeem another ill you have committed,
That my poor innocent daughter perish not,
By your vild sin, whom you have got with child.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Here begin all my compassion: O poor soul!
She is with child by Contarino, and he dead,
By whom should she preserve her fame to the world,
But by myself that loved her above the world?
There never was a way more honourable,
To exercise my virtue, than to father it,
And preserve her credit, and to marry her.
I will suppose her Contarino's widow, bequeathed to me
Upon his Death: for sure she was his wife,
But that the Ceremony of the Church was wanting.
Report this to her, Madam, and withal,
That never father did conceive more joy
For the birth of an heir, than I to understand,
She had such confidence in me. I will not now
Press a Visit upon her, till you have prepared her:
For I do read in your distraction,
Should I be brought of the sudden to her presence,
Either the hasty fright, or else the shame
May blast the fruit within her. I will leave you,
To commend as loyal faith and service to her,
As ever heart harboured; by my hope of bliss,
I never lived to do good act but this.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Withal if you be wise,
Remember what the mother has revealed
Of Romelio's treachery.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A most noble fellow in his loyalty.
I read what worthy comforts I have lost
In my dear Contarino, and all adds
To my despair. -- Within there.
Fetch the picture hangs in my inner closet. I remember,
I let a word slip of Romelio's practise
At the Surgeons: no matter I can salve it,
I have deeper vengeance that is preparing for him,
To let him live and kill him that is revenge
I meditate upon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So, hang it up.
I was enjoined by the party ought that picture,
Forty years since, ever when I was vexed,
To look upon that: what was his meaning in it,
I know not, but methinks upon the sudden,
It has furnished me with mischief such a plot,
As never mother dreamt of Here begins
My part in the play: my son's estate is sunk,
By loss at sea and he has nothing left,
But the Land his father left him. It is concluded,
The Law shall undo him. Come hither,
I have a weighty secret to impart,
But I would have thee first confirm to me,
How I may trust, that thou canst keep my counsel,
Beyond death.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Why Mistress, it is your only way,
To enjoin me first that I reveal to you
The worst act I ever did in all my life:
So one secret shall bind one another.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou instructest me
Most ingenuously, for indeed it is not fit,
Where any act is plotted, that is naught,
Any of counsel to it should be good,
And in a thousand ills have happed in the world,
The intelligence of one another's shame,
Have wrought far more effectually than the tie
Of Conscience, or Religion.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: But think not, Mistress,
That any sin which ever I committed,
Did concern you, for proving false in one thing,
You were a fool, if ever you would trust me
In the least matter of weight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou hast lived with me
These forty years; we have grown old together,
As many Ladies and their women do,
With talking nothing, and with doing less:
We have spent our life in that which least concerns life,
Only in putting on our clothes; and now I think of it,
I have been a very courtly Mistress to thee,
I have given thee good words, but no deeds, now is the time,
To requite all; my son has six Lordships left him.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: It is truth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But he cannot live four days to enjoy them.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Have you poisoned him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, the poison is yet but brewing.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You must minister it to him with all privacy.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Privacy? It shall be given him
In open Court, I will make him swallow it
Before the Judges face: if he be Master
Of poor ten arpents of land forty hours longer,
Let the world repute me an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: So it will I hope.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O thou canst not conceive
My unimitable plot; let us to my ghostly Father,
Were first I will have thee make a promise
To keep my counsel, and then I will employ thee
In such a subtle combination,
Which will require to make the practise fit,
Four Devils, five Advocates to a woman's wit.

div1.head: Actvs Qvartvs, Scena Prima.
div1.stage: Enter Leonora, Sanitonella at one doore, Winifrid, Register: at the other Ariosto

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Take her into your Office sir, she has that in her
Belly, will dry up your ink I can tell you.
This is the man that is your learned Counsel,
A fellow that will troll it off with tongue:
He never goes without Restorative powder
Of the lungs of Fox in his pocket, and Malligo Raisins
To make him long winded. Sir, this Gentlewoman
Entreats your Counsel in an honest cause,
Which please you sir, this Brief, my own poor labour
Will give you light of.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Do you call this a Brief?
Here is as I weigh them, some fourscore sheets of paper.
What would they weigh if there were cheese
Wrapped in them, or Fig-dates.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Joy come to you, you are merry;
We call this but a Brief in our Office.
The scope of the business lies in the Margent sheet.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Methinks you prate too much.
I never could endure an honest cause
With a long Prologue to it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You trouble him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What is here? O strange; I have lived this sixty years,
Yet in all my practise never did shake hands
With a cause so odious. Sirra, are you her knave?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No sir, I am a Clarke.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Why you whoreson fogging Rascal,
Are there not whores enough for Presentations,
Of Overseers, wrong the will of the Dead,
Oppressions of Widows, or young Orphans,
Wicked Diversions, or your vicious cause
Of , to content a woman,
But you must find new stratagems, new pursuits,
O women, as the Ballet lives to tell you,
What will you shortly come to?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Your Fee is ready sir.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: The Devil take such Fees,
And all such Suits in the tail of thee; see the slave
Has writ false Latin: sirra Ignorance,
Were you ever at the University?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Never sir:
It is well known to divers I have Commenced
In a Pew of our Office.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Where, in a Pew of your Office?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I have been dry-foundered with it this four years,
Seldom found Non resident from my desk.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Non resident Subsumner:
I will tear your Libel for abusing that word,
By virtue of the Clergy.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?
It cost me four nights labour.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Hadst thou been drunk so long,
Thou hadst done our Court better Service.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, you do forget your gravity, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Cry ye mercy, do I so?
And as I take it, you do very little remember,
Either womanhood, or Christianity: why do ye meddle
With that seducing knave, that is good for naught,
Unless it be to fill the Office full of Fleas,
Or a Winter itch, wears that spacious Inkhorn
All a Vacation only to cure Tetters,
And his Penknife to weed Corns from the splay toes
Of the right worshipful of the Office.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You make bold with me sir.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Woman, you are mad, I will swear it, and have more need
Of a Physician than a Lawyer.
The melancholy humour flows in your face,
Your painting cannot hide it: such vild suits
Disgrace our Courts, and those make honest Lawyers
Stop their own ears, whilst they plead and that is the reason
Your younger men that have good conscience,
Wear such large Night-caps; go old woman, go pray,
For Lunacy, or else the Devil himself
Has taken possession of thee; may like cause:
In any Christian Court never find name:
Bad Suits, and not the Law, bred the Law's shame.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sure the old man is frantic.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Plague on his gouty fingers,
Were all of his mind, to entertain no suits,
But such they thought were honest, sure our Lawyers
Would not purchase half so fast:
But here is the man,
Learned Seignior Contilupo, here is a fellow
Of another piece believe it, I must make shift
With the foul Copy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Business to me?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: To you sir, from this Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: She is welcome.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: It is a foul Copy sir, you will hardly read it,
There is twenty double ducats, can you read sir?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Exceeding well, very, very exceeding well.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: This man will be saved, he can read; Lord, Lord,
To see, what money can do, be the hand never so foul,
Somewhat will be picked out of it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is not this ?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No, that is struck out sir;
And whereever you find in these papers,
Give it a dash sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I shall be mindful of it:
In troth you write a pretty Secretary,
Your Secretary hand ever takes best in mine opinion.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Sir, I have been in France,
And there believe it your Court hand generally,
Takes beyond thought.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Even as a man is traded in it.

sp.speaker: San
sp.l: That I could not think of this virtuous Gentleman
Before I went to the the other Hog-rubber.
Why this was wont to give young Clerks half fees,
To help him to Clients. Your opinion in the Case sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am struck with wonder almost ecstasy,
With this most goodly Suite.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It is the fruit of a most hearty penitence.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: It is a Case shall leave a President to all the world,
In our succeeding Annals, and deserves
Rather a spacious public Theatre,
Than a pent Court for Audience; it shall teach
All Ladies the right path to rectify their issue.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Lo you, here is a man of comfort.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And you shall go unto a peaceful grave,
Discharged of such a guilt, as would have lain
Howling forever at your wounded heart,
And rose with you to Judgment.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: O give me such a Lawyer, as will think of the day of Judgment.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You must urge the business against him
As spitefully as may be.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Doubt not. What is he summoned?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes, and the Court will sit within this half hour.
Peruse your Notes, you have very short warning.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Never fear you that:
Follow me worthy Lady, and make account
This Suite is ended already.

div1.stage: Enter Officers preparing seats for the Iudges, to them Ercole muffled.

sp.speaker: 1. Of.
sp.l: You would have a private seat sir.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Of.
sp.l: Here is a Closet belongs to the Court,
Where you may hear all unseen.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I thank you; there is money.

sp.speaker: 2 Of.
sp.l: I give you your thanks again sir.

sp.speaker: Cont,
sp.l: Is it possible Romelio is persuaded,
You are gone to the East Indies.

sp.speaker: 1. Sur.
sp.l: Most confidently.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But do you mean to go?

sp.speaker: 2. Su.
sp.l: How? go to the East Indies?
sp.p:
And so many Hollanders gone to fetch sauce for their pickled
Herrings; some have been peppered there too lately,
but I pray, being thus well recovered of your wounds,
sp.l: Why do you not reveal yourself?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That my fair Iolenta should be rumoured
To be with child by noble Ercole,
Makes me expect to what a violent issue
These passages will come. I hear her brother
Is marrying the Infant she goes with, fore it be borne,
As if it be a Daughter,
To the Duke of Austrias Nephew; if a Son,
Into the Noble ancient Family
Of the Palauafini: He is a subtle Devil.
And I do wonder what strange Suite in Law,
Has happed between him and his mother.

sp.speaker: 1. Sur.
sp.l: It is whispered among the Lawyers,
It will undo him forever.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Do you hear Officers?
You must take special care, that you let in
No Brachygraphy men, to take notes.

sp.speaker: 1. Of.
sp.l: No sir?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: By no means,
We cannot have a Cause of any fame,
But you must have scurvy pamphlets, and lewd Ballets
Engendered of it presently.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Have you broke fast yet?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: It was very ill done of you:
For this cause will be long apleading; but not matter,
I have a modicum in my Buckram bag,
To stop your stomach.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: What is it? Green ginger?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Green ginger, nor Pellitory of Spaine neither,
Yet it will stop a hollow tooth better than either of them.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Pray what is it?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: look you,
It is a very lovely Pudding-pie,
Which we Clerks find great relief in.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I shall have no stomach.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No matter if you have not, I may pleasure
Some of our Learned Council with it; I have done it
Many a time and often, when a Cause
Has proved like an after-game at Irish.

stage.p:
Enter Crispiano like a Iudge, with another Iudge, Contilupo,
and another Lawyer at one Barye, Romelio, Ariosto, at
another, Leonora with a blacke vaile ouer
her, and Iulio.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: It is a strange Suite, is Leonora come.

sp.speaker: Conti.
sp.l: She is here my Lord; make way there for the Lady.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Take off her Veil: it seems she is ashamed
To look her cause in the face.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: She is sick, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: She is mad my Lord, and would be kept more dark.
sp.p:
By your favour sir, I have now occasion to be at your elbow,
and within this half hour shall entreat you to be
angry, very angry.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Is Romelio come?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I am here my Lord, and called I do protest,
To answer what I know not, for as yet
I am wholly ignorant, of what the Court
Will charge me with.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I assure you, the proceeding
Is most unequal then, for I perceive,
The Counsel of the adverse party furnished
With full Instruction.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Pray my Lord, who is my accuser?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: It is your mother.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: She has discovered Contarino's murder:
If she prove so unnatural, to call
My life in question, I am armed to suffer
This to end all my losses.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Sir, we will do you this favour,
You shall hear the Accusation,
Which; being known, we will adjourn the Court,
Till a fortnight hence, you may provide your Counsel.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: I advise you, take their proffer,
Or else the Lunacy runs in a blood,
You are more mad than she.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What are you sir?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: An angry fellow that would do thee good,
For goodness sake itself, I do protest,
Neither for love nor money.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Prithee stand further, I shall gall your gout else.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come, come, I know you for an East Indy Merchant,
You have a spice of pride in you still.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: My Lord, I am so strengthened in my innocence,
For any the least shadow of a crime,
Committed against my mother, or the world,
That she can charge me with, here do I make it
My humble suite, only this hour and place,
May give it as full hearing, and as free,
And unrestrained a Sentence.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Be not too confident you have cause to fear.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let fear dwell with Earth-quakes,
Shipwrecks at Sea, or Prodigies in heaven,
I cannot set myself so many fathom
Beneath the height of my true heart, as fear.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Very fine words I assure you, if they were to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Well, have your entreaty:
And if your own credulity undo you,
Blame not the Court hereafter: fall to your Plea.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: May it please your Lordship. and the reverend Court,
To give me leave to open to you a Case
So rare, so altogether void of President,
That I do challenge all the spacious Volumes,
Of the whole Civil Law to show the like.
We are of Counsel for this Gentlewoman,
We have received our Fee, yet the whole course
Of what we are to speak, is quite against her,
Yet we deserve our fee too. There stands one,
Romelio the Merchant; I will name him to you,
Without either title or addition:
For those false beams of his supposed honour,
As void of true heat, as are all painted fires,
Or Glowworms in the dark, suite him all basely,
As if he had bought his Gentry from the Herald,
With money got by extortion: I will first
Produce this Aesop's Crow, as he stands forfeit,
For the long use of his gay borrowed plumes,
And then let him hop naked: I come to the point,
It has been a Dream in Naples, very near
This eight and thirty years, that this Romelio,
Was nobly descended, he has ranked himself
With the Nobility, shamefully usurped
Their place, and in a kind of saucy pride,
Which like to Mushrooms, ever grow most rank,
When they do spring from dung-hills, sought to oversway,
The Fliski, the Grimaldi, Dori,
And all the ancient pillars of our State;
View now what he is come to: this poor thing
Without a name, this Cuckoo hatched in the nest
Of a Hedge-sparrow.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Speaks he all this to me?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Only to you sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I do not ask thee, prithee hold thy prating.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Why very good, you will be presently
As angry as I could wish.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: What title shall I set to this base coin,
He has no name, and for his aspect he seems,
A Giant in a May-game, that within
Is nothing but a Porter's I will undertake,
He had as good have travelled all his life
With Gypsies: I will sell him to any man
For an hundred Chickens, and he that buys him of me,
Shall lose by the hand too.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Lo, what you are come to:
You that did scorn to trade in anything,
But Gold or Spices, or your Cochineal,
He rates you now at poor Iohn.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Out upon thee, I would thou wert of his side,

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Would you so?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The devil and thee together on each hand,
To prompt the Lawyers memory when he founders.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Signior Contilupo, the Court holds it fit,
You leave this stale declaiming against the person,
And come to the matter.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Now I shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: It shows a poor malicious eloquence,
And it is strange, men of your gravity
Will not forgo it: verily, I presume,
If you but heard yourself speaking with my ears,
Your phrase would be more modest.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: Good my Lord, be assured,
I will leave all circumstance, and come to the purpose:
This Romelio is a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How, a Bastard? O mother,
Now the day begins grow hot on your side.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: Why she is your accuser.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l:
I had forgot that; was my father married to any
other woman, at the time of my begetting?

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: That is not the business.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I turn me then to you that were my mother,
But by what name I am to call you now,
You must instruct me: were you ever married
To my father?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To my shame I speak it, never.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Not to Franscisco Romelio?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: May it please your Lordships,
To him I was, but he was not his father.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Good my Lord, give us leave in a few words,
To expound the Riddle, and to make it plain,
Without the least of scruple: for I take it,
There cannot be more lawful proof in the world,
Than the oath of the mother.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Well then, to your proofs, and be not tedious.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: I will conclude in a word:
Some nine and thirty years since, which was the time,
This woman was married, Francisco Romelio,
This Gentleman's putative father, and her husband
Being not married to her past a fortnight,
Would needs go travel; did so, and continued
In France and the Low-Countries eleven months:
Take special note of the time, I beseech your Lordship,
For it makes much to the business: in his absence
He left behind to sojourn at his house
A Spanish Gentleman, a fine spruce youth
By the Ladies confession, and you may be sure
He was no Eunuch neither; he was one
Romelio loved very dearly, as oft haps,
No man alive more welcome to the husband
Than he that makes him Cuckold.
This Gentleman I say,
Breaking all Laws of Hospitality,
Got his friends wife with child, a full two months
Fore the husband returned.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Good sir, forget not the Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: I will pinch by the buttock, to put you in mind of it.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: Prithee hold thy prating.
What is to be practised now my Lord? Marry this,
Romelio being a young novice, not acquainted
With this precedence, very innocently
Returning home from travel, finds his wife
Grown an excellent good Housewife, for she had set
Her women to spin Flax, and to that use,
Had in a study which was built of stone,
Stored up at least an hundredth weight of flax:
Marry such a thread as was to be spun from the flax,
I think the like was never heard of.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: What was that?

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: You may be certain, she would lose no time,
In bragging that her Husband had got up
Her belly: to be short, at seven months' end,
Which was the time of her delivery,
And when she felt herself to fall in travel,
She makes her Waiting woman, as by mischance,
Set fire to the flax, the flight whereof,
As they pretend, causes this Gentlewoman
To fall in pain, and be delivered
Eight weeks afore her reckoning.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Now sir, remember the Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The Midwife strait howls out, there was no hope
Of the infants life, swaddles it in a flayed Lambskin,
As a Bird hatched too early, makes it up
With three quarters of a face, that made it look
Like a Changeling, cries out to Romelio,
To have it Christened, least it should depart
Without that it came for: and thus are many served,
That take care to get Gossips for those children,
To which they might be Godfathers themselves,
And yet be no arch-Puritans neither.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p:
Pray my Lord give him way, you spoil his oratory
else: thus would they jest were they feed, to open their
sisters cases.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: You have urged enough;
You first affirm, her husband was away from her
Eleven months.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: And at seven months' end,
After his return she was delivered
Of this Romelio, and had gone her full time.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: True my Lord.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: So by this account this Gentleman was begot,
In his supposed fathers absence.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: You have it fully.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: A most strange Suite this, it is beyond example,
Either time past, or present, for a woman,
To publish her own dishonour voluntarily,
Without being called in question, some forty years
After the sin committed, and her Counsel
To enlarge the offence with as much Oratory,
As ever I did hear them in my life,
Defend a guilty woman; it is most strange:
Or why with such a poisoned violence
Should she labour her son's undoing: we observe
Obedience of creatures to the Law of Nature,
Is the stay of the whole world; here that Law is broke,
For though our Civil Law makes difference
Tween the base, and the legitimate; compassionate Nature
Makes them equal, nay, she many times prefers them.
I pray resolve me sir, have not you and your mother
Had some Suite in Law together lately?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: None my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No? no contention about parting your goods?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not any.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No flaw, no unkindness?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: None that ever arrived at my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Bethink yourself, this cannot choose but savour
Of a woman's malice deeply; and I fear,
You are practised upon most devilishly.
How happed Gentlewoman, you revealed this no sooner?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: While my husband lived, my Lord, I durst not.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I should rather ask you, why you reveal it now?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Because my Lord, I loathed that such a sin
Should lie smothered with me in my grave; my penitence,
Though to my shame, prefers the revealing of it
Above worldly reputation.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Your penitence?
Might not your penitence have been as hearty,
Though it had never summoned to the Court
Such a conflux of people.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed I might have confessed it,
Privately to the Church, I grant; but you know repentance
Is nothing without satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Satisfaction? why your Husband is dead,
What satisfaction can you make him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The greatest satisfaction in the world, my Lord,
To restore the land to the right heir, and that is my daughter.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: O she is straight begot then.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Very well, may it please this honourable Court,
If he be a bastard, and must forfeit his land for it,
She has proved herself a strumpet, and must lose
Her Dower, let them go abegging together.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Who shall pay us our Fees then?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Most just.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: You may see now what an old house
You are like to pull over your head, Dame.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Could I conceive this Publication
Grew from a hearty penitence, I could bear
My undoing the more patiently; but my Lord,
There is no reason, as you said even now,
To satisfy me: but this suite of hers
Springs from a devilish malice, and her pretence,
Of a grieved Conscience, and Religion,
Like to the horrid Powder-Treason in England,
Has a most bloody unnatural revenge
Hid under it: O the violencies of women!
Why they are creatures made up and compounded
Of all monsters, poisoned Minerals,
And sorcerous Herbs that grows.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Are you angry yet?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Would men express a bad one,
Let him forsake all natural example,
And compare one to another; they have no more mercy,
Than ruinous fires in great tempests.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Take heed you do not crack your voice sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Hard-hearted creatures, good for nothing else,
But to wind dead bodies.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l:
Yes, to weave seaming lace with the bones of their
Husbands that were long since buried, and curse them
when they tangle.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yet why do I
Take Bastardy so distastefully, when in the world,
A many things that are essential parts
Of greatness, are but by-slips, and are fathered
On the wrong parties.
Preferment in the world a many times,
Basely begotten: nay, I have observed
The immaculate Justice of a poor man's cause,
In such a Court as this, has not known whom
To call Father, which way to direct itself
For Compassion: but I forget my temper,
Only that I may stop that Lawyers throat,
I do beseech the Court, and the whole world,
They will not think the baselier of me,
For the vice of a mother: for that woman's sin,
To which you all dare swear when it was done,
I would not give my consent.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Stay, here is an Accusation,
But here is no proof; what was the Spanyards name
You accuse of adultery?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Don Crispiano, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: What part of Spaine was he born in?

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: In Castile.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This may prove my father.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: And my Master, my Client is spoiled then.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I knew that Spanyard well: if you be a Bastard,
Such a man being your father, I dare vouch you
A Gentleman; and in that Signior Contilupo,
Your Oratory went a little too far.
When do we name Don Iohn of Austria,
The Emperor's son, but with reverence:
And I have known in divers Families,
The Bastards the greater spirits; but to the purpose,
What time was this Gentleman begot?
And be sure you lay your time right.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Now the metal comes to the Touchstone.

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.l: In Anno seventy one, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Very well, seventy one:
The Battle of Lepanto was fought in it,
A most remarkable time, it will lie for no man's pleasure:
And what proof is there more than the affirmation of the
Mother, of this corporal dealing?

sp.speaker: Contil.
sp.p:
The deposition of a Waiting woman served
her the same time.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Where is our Solicitor with the Waiting woman?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Room for the bag and baggage.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Here my Lord, Oretenus.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: And what can you say Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Please your Lordship, I was the party that dealt
In the business, and brought them together.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And conveyed letters between them.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: What needed letters, when it is said he lodged in her house?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A running Ballad now and then to her Viol,
For he was never well, but when he was fiddling.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p:
Speak to the purpose, did you ever know them
bed together?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: No my Lord,
But I have brought him to the bed side.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: That was somewhat near to the business;
And what, did you help him off with his shoes?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: He wore no shoes, if it please you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No? what then, Pumps?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Boots were not fit for his journey.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: He wore Tennis-court woollen slippers,
For fear of creaking sir, and making a noise,
To wake the rest of the house.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Well, and what did he there,
In his Tennis-court woollen slippers?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Please your Lordship, question me in Latin,
For the cause is very foul; the Examiner of the Court
Was fain to get it out of me alone in the Counting-house,
Cause he would not spoil the youth of the Office.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Here is a Latin spoon, and a long one,
To feed with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I would be loath to be ignorant that way,
For I hope to marry a Proctor, and take my pleasure abroad
At the Commencements with him.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Come closer to the business.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I will come as close as modesty will give me leave.

Truth is, every morning when he lay
with her,
I made a Caudle for him, by the appointment
Of my Mistress, which he would still refuse,
And call for small drink.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Small drink?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: For a Iulipe.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And said he was wondrous thirsty.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: What is this to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Most effectual, my Lord,
I have heard them laugh together extremely,
And the Curtain rods fall from the tester of the bed,
sp.p:
And he never came from her, but he thrust money in my
hand; and once in truth, he would have had some dealing
with me, which I took; he thought it would be the only
way in the world to make me keep counsel the better.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: That is a stinger, it is a good wench, be not daunted.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Did you ever find the print of two in the bed?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
What a question is that to be asked, may it please your
Lordship. it is to be thought he lay nearer to her than so.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: What age are you of Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: About six and forty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Anno seventy one,
And Romelio is thirty eight: by that reckoning,
You were a Bawd at eight year old: now verily,
You fell to the Trade betimes.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: There you are from the Bias.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I do not know my age directly; sure I am elder,
I can remember two great frosts, and three great plagues,
And the loss of Callis, and the first coming up
Of the Breeches with the great Codpiece,
And I pray what age do you take me of then?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well come off again.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: An old hunted Hare, she has all her doubles.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: For your own gravities,
And the reverence of the Court, I do beseech you,
Rip up the cause no further, but proceed to Sentence.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: One question more and I have done:
Might not this Crispiano, this Spanyard,
Lie with your Mistress at some other time,
Either afore or after, than in the absence of her husband?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Are you certain of that?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: On my soul, never.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: That is well he never lay with her,
But in anno seventy one, let that be remembered.
Stand you aside a while. Mistress, the truth is,
I knew this Crispiano, lived in Naples
At the same time, and loved the Gentleman
As my bosom friend; and as I do remember,
The Gentleman did leave his Picture with you,
If age or neglect have not in so long time ruined it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I preserve it still my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I pray let me see it, let me see the face
I then loved so much to look on.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Fetch it.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I shall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No, no, Gentlewoman,
I have other business for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Sur.
sp.l: Now were the time to cut Romelio's throat,
And accuse him for your murder.

sp.speaker: Contar.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: 2. Sur.
sp.l: Will you not let us be men of fashion,
And down with him now he is going?

sp.speaker: Contar.
sp.l: Peace, let us attend the sequel.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I commend you Lady,
There was a main matter of Conscience,
How many ills spring from Adultery!
First, the supreme Law that is violated,
Nobility oft stained with Bastardy,
Inheritance of Land falsely possessed,
The husband scorned, wife shamed, and babes unblessed.

So, hang it up in the
Court; you have heard,
What has been urged against Romelio.
Now my definitive sentence in this cause,
Is, I will give no sentence at all.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: No, I cannot, for I am made a party.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: How a party? here are fine cross tricks,
What the devil will he do now?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Signior Ariosto, his Majesty of Spaine,
Confers my Place upon you by this Patent,
Which till this urgent hour I have kept
From your knowledge: may you thrive in it, noble sir,
And do that which but few in our place do,
Go to their grave uncurst.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: This Law business
Will leave me so small leisure to serve God,
I shall serve the King the worse.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Is he a Judge?
We must then look for all Conscience, and no Law,
He will beggar all his followers.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Sir, I am of your Counsel, for the cause in hand
Was begun at such a time, fore you could speak;
You had need therefore have one speak for you.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Stay, I do here first make protestation,
I never took fee of this Romelio,
For being of his Council, which may free me,
Being now his Judge, for the imputation
Of taking a Bribe. Now sir, speak your mind.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: I do first entreat, that the eyes of all here present,
May be fixed upon this

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O, I am confounded, this is Crispiano.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: This is my father, how the Judges have bleated him.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You may see truth will out in spite of the Devil.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Behold, I am the shadow of this shadow,
Age has made me so; take from me forty years,
And I was such a Summer fruit as this,
At least the Painter feigned so: for indeed,
Painting and Epitaphs are both alike,
They flatter us, and say we have been thus:
But I am the party here, that stands accused,
For Adultery with this woman, in the year
Seventy one: now I call you my Lord to witness,
Four years before that time, I went to the Indies,
And till this month, did never set my foot since
In Europe; and for any former incontinence,
She has vowed there was never any: what remains then,
But this is a mere practise against her son,
And I beseech the Court it may be sifted,
And most severely punished.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Vds foot, we are spoiled,
Why my Client is proved an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: What do you think will become of me now?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: you will be made dance lachrimae I fear at a Carts tail.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: You Mistress, where are you now?
Your Tennis-court slips, and your taken drink
In a morning for your hot liver; where is the man,
Would have had some dealing with you, that you might
Keep counsel the better.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: May it please the Court, I am but a young thing,
And was drawn arsey, varsey into the business.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: How young? of five and forty?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Five and forty, if shall please you!
I am not five and twenty:
She made me colour my hair with Bean-flower,
To seem elder than I was; and then my rotten teeth,
With eating sweet-meats: why, should a Farrier
Look in my mouth, he might mistake my age.
O Mistress, Mistress, you are an honest woman,
And you may be ashamed of it, to abuse the Court thus.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Whatsoever I have attempted,
Against my own fame, or the reputation
Of that Gentleman my son, the Lord Contarino
Was cause of it.

sp.speaker: Conta.
sp.l: Who I?

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: He that should have married your daughter?
It was a plot belike then to confer
The land on her that should have been his wife.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: More than I have said already, all the world
Shall never extract from me; I entreat from both,
Your equal pardons.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And I from you sir.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: Sirra, stand you aside,
I will talk with you hereafter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I could never away with after reckonings.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And now my Lords, I do most voluntarily
Confine myself unto a stricter prison,
And a severer penance, than this Court can impose,
I am entered into Religion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I the cause of this practise; this ungodly woman,
Has sold herself to falsehood: I will now reveal myself.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Stay my Lord, here is a window
To let in more light to the Court.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Mercy upon me! O, that thou art living
Is mercy indeed!

sp.speaker: 1. Sur.
sp.l: Stay, keep in your shell a little longer?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: I am Ercole.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: A guard upon him for the death of Contarino.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: I obey the arrest of the Court.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O sir, you are happily restored to life,
And to us your friends.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Away, thou art the Traitor:
I only live to challenge; this former suite,
Touched but thy fame, this accusation
Reaches to thy fame and life: the brave Contarino
Is generally supposed slain by this hand.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How knows he the contrary?

sp.speaker: Erc,
sp.l: But truth is,
Having received from me some certain wounds,
Which were not mortal, this vild murderer,
Being by Will deputed Overseer
Of the Nobleman's Estate, to his sisters use,
That he might make him sure from surviving,
To revoke that Will, stole to him in his bed, and killed him.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Strange, unheard of, more practise yet!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What proof of this?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: The report of his mother delivered to me,
In distraction for Contarino's death.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: For my death? I begin to apprehend,
That the violence of this woman's love to me,
Might practise the disinheriting of her son.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: What say you to this Leonora?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Such a thing I did utter out of my distraction:
But how the Court will censure that report,
I leave to their wisdoms.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: My opinion is,
That this late slander urged against her son,
Takes from her all manner of credit:
She that would not stick to deprive him of his living,
Will as little tender his life.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I beseech the Court,
I may retire myself to my place of penance,
I have vowed myself and my woman.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Go when you please: what should move you
Be thus forward in the accusation?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: My love to Contarino.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: O, it bore very bitter fruit at your last meeting.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: It is true: but I begun to love him,
When I had most cause to hate him, when our bloods
Embraced each other, then I pitied,
That so much valour should be hazarded
On the fortune of a single Rapier,
And not spent against the Turk.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Stay sir, be well advised,
There is no testimony but your own,
To approve you slew him, therefore no other way
To decide it, but by Duel.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, I dare affirm against all the world,
This Noble man speaks truth.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: You will make yourself a party in the Duel.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let him, I will fight with the both, sixteen of them.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Sir, I do not know you.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: Yes but you have forgot me, you and I have sweat
In the Breach together at Malta.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Cry you mercy, I have known of your Nation
Brave Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: Now if my father
Have any true spirit in him, I will recover
His good opinion Do you hear? do not swear sir,
For I dare swear, that you will swear a lie,
A very filthy, stinking, rotten lie:
And if the Lawyers think not this sufficient,
I will give the lie in the stomach,
That is somewhat deeper than the throat;
Both here, and all France over and over,
From Marselys, or Bayon, to Callis Sands,
And there draw my Sword upon thee,
And new scour it in the gravel of thy kidneys.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: You the Defendant charged with the murder,
And you Second there,
Must be committed to the custody
Of the Knight-Marshall; and the Court gives charge,
They be tomorrow ready in the Lists
Before the Sun be risen.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I do entreat the Court, there be a guard
Placed over my Sister, that she enter not
Into Religion: she is rich my Lords,
And the persuasions of Fryers, to gain
All her possessions to their Monasteries,
May do much upon her.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: We will take order for her.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.l: There is a Nun too you have got with child,
How will you dispose of her?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You question me, as if I were graved already,
When I have quenched this wildfire
In Ercoles tame blood, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: You have judged today
A most confused practise, that takes end
In as bloody a trial, and we may observe
By these great persons, and their indirect
Proceedings, shadowed in a veil of State,
Mountains are deformed heaps, swelled up aloft,
Vales wholesomer, though lower, and trod on oft.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well, I will put up my papers,
And send them to France for a President,
That they may not say yet, but for one strange
Law suite, we come somewhat near them.

div1.head: Actvs Qvintvs, Scena Prima.
div1.stage: Enter Iolenta, and Angiololla great bellied.

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: How dost thou friend? welcome, thou and I
Were playfellows together, little children,
So small awhile ago, that I presume,
We are neither of us wise yet.

sp.speaker: Angi.
sp.l: A most sad truth on my part.

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: Why do you pluck your veil
Over your face?

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: If you will believe truth,
There is naught more terrible to a guilty heart,
As the eye of a respected friend.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Say friend, are you quick with child?

sp.speaker: Angi.
sp.l: Too sure.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: How could you know.
Of your first child when you quickened?

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: How could you know friend?
It is reported you are in the same taking.

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, so it is given out:
But Ercoles coming to life again, has shrunk,
And made invisible my great belly; yes faith,
My being with child was merely in supposition,
Not practise.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: You are happy, what would I give,
To be a Maid again?

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: Would you, to what purpose?
I would never give great purchase for that thing
Is in danger every hour to be lost: pray thee laugh.
A Boy or a Girl for a wager?

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: What heaven please.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: Nay, nay, will you venture
A chain of Pearl with me whether?

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: I will lay nothing,
I have ventured too much for it already, my fame.
I make no question sister, you have heard
Of the intended combat.

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: O what else?
I have a sweet heart in it, against a brother.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: And I a dead friend, I fear; what good counsel
Can you minister unto me?

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: Faith only this,
Since there is no means in the world to hinder it,
Let thou and I wench get as far as we can
From the noise of it.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: No matter, any whither.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: Any whither, so you go not by sea:
I cannot abide rough water.

sp.speaker: Iolen.
sp.l: Not endure to be tumbled? say no more then,
We will be land-soldiers for that trick: take heart,
Thy boy shall be born a brave Roman.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: O you mean to go to Rome then.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Within there. Bear this Letter
To the Lord Ercole. Now wench, I am for thee
All the world over.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: I like your shade pursue you.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.p:
Well, I do not think but to see you as pretty a
piece of Law-flesh.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: In time I may,
Marry I am resolved to take a new way for it
sp.p:
You have Lawyers take their Clients fees, and their backs
are no sooner turned, but they call them fools, and laugh
at them.

sp.speaker: Prosp.
sp.l: That is ill done of them.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: There is one thing too that has a vild abuse in it.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Marry this,
sp.p:
That no Proctor in the Term time be tolerated to go to
the Tavern above six times in the forenoon.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Why man?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: O sir, it makes their Clients overtaken,
And become friends sooner than they would be.

stage.p:
Enter Ercole with a letter, and Contarino comming
in Friers habits, as hauing bin at the Bathanites,
a Ceremony vsed afore these Combates.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Leave the Room, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Wherefore should I with such an obstinacy,
Conceal myself any longer. I am taught,
That all the blood which will be shed tomorrow,
Must fall upon my head; one question
Shall fix it or untie it: Noble brother,
I would fain know how it is possible,
When it appears you love the fair Iolenta
With such a height of fervor, you were ready
To father another's child, and marry her,
You would so suddenly engage yourself,
To kill her brother, one that ever stood,
Your loyal and firm friend?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Sir, I will tell you,
My love, as I have formerly protested
To Contarino, whose unfortunate end,
The traitor wrought: and here is one thing more,
Deads all good thoughts of him, which I now received
From Iolenta.

sp.speaker: Cont,
sp.l: In a Letter?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Yes, in this Letter:
For having sent to her to be resolved
Most truly, who was father of the child,
She writes back, that the shame she goes withal,
Was begot by her brother.

sp.speaker: Cont,
sp.l: O most incestuous villain.

sp.speaker: Erc.
sp.l: I protest, before I thought it was Contarinos Issue,
And for that would have veiled her dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cont,
sp.l: No more.
Has the Armourer brought the weapons?

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Cont,
sp.l: I will no more think of her.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Of my mother, I was thinking of my mother.
Call the Armourer.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: You do love me sir, you say?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: O most entirely.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And you will marry me?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Nay, I will do more than that.
The fashion of the world is many times,
To make a woman naught, and afterwards
To marry her: but I on the contrary,
Will make you honest first, and afterwards
Proceed to the wedlock.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Honest, what mean you by that?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: I mean, that your suborning the late Law suite,
Has got you a filthy report: now there is no way,
But to do some excellent piece of honesty,
To recover your good name.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: You shall straight go, and reveal to your old
Mistress, for certain truth, Contarino is alive.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: How, living?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Yes, he is living.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: No, I must not tell her of it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: No, why?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: For she did bind me yesterday by oath,
Never more to speak of him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: You shall reveal it then to Ariosto the Judge.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: By no means, he has heard me
Tell so many lies in the Court, he will never believe me.
What if I told it to the Capuchin?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: You cannot think of a better; for as your young Mistress.
Who as you told me, has persuaded you,
To run away with her: let her have her humour.
I have a suite Romelio left in the house,
The habit of a Jew, that I will put on,
And pretending I am robbed, by break of day,
Procure all Passengers to be brought back,
And by the way reveal myself, and discover
The Comical event. They say she is a little mad,
This will help to cure her: go, go presently,
And reveal it to the Capuchin.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Sir, I shall

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.p:
A pox on it, I have undertaken the challenge very
foolishly: what if I do not appear to answer it?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It would be absolute conviction
Of Cowardice, and Perjury; and the Dane,
May to your public shame, reverse your Arms,
Or have them ignominiously fastened
Under his horse tail.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I do not like that so well.
I see then I must fight whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Prosp.
sp.l: How does Romelio bear himself? They say,
He has almost brained one of our cunningest Fencers,
That practiced with him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Very certain; and now you talk of fencing,
Do not you remember the Welsh Gentleman,
That was travelling to Rome upon return?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: No, what of him?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: There was a strange experiment of a Fencer.

sp.speaker: Pras.
sp.l: What was that?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The Welshman in his play, do what the Fencer could,
Hung still an arse; he could not for his life
Make him come on bravely: till one night at supper,
Observing what a deal of Parma cheese
His Scholar devoured, goes ingeniously
The next morning, and makes a spacious button
For his foil of toasted cheese, and as sure as you live,
That made him come on the burliest.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Possible!

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Marry it taught him an ill grace in his play,
It made him gape still, gape as he put in for it,
As I have seen some hungry Usher.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The toasting of it belike,
Was to make it more supple, had he chanced
To have hit him on the chaps.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not unlikely. Who can tell me,
If we may breath in the Duel?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nor drink?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That is scurvy, anger will make me very dry.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: You mistake sir, it is sorrow that is very dry.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Not always sir, I have known sorrow very wet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: In rainy weather.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No, when a woman has come dropping wet
Out of a Cucking-stool.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then it was wet indeed sir.

div1.stage: Enter Romelio very melancholly, and the Capuchin.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Having from Leonoras Waiting woman,
Delivered a most strange Intelligence
Of Contarino's recovery, I am come
To sound Romelio's penitence; that performed,
To end these errors by discovering,
What she related to me. Peace to you sir,
Pray Gentlemen, let the freedom of this Room
Be mine a little. Nay sir, you may stay.
Will you pray with me?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No, no, the world and I
Have not made up our accounts yet.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Shall I pray for you?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Whether you do or no, I care not.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O you have a dangerous voyage to take.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: No matter, I will be mine own Pilot:
Do not you trouble your head with the business.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Pray tell me, do not you meditate of death?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Phew, I took out that Lesson,
When I once lay sick of an Ague: I do now
Labour for life, for life. Sir, can you tell me,
Whether your Tolledo, or your Millain Blade
Be best tempered?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: These things you know, are out of my practice.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But these are things you know,
I must practice with tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Were I in your case,
I should present to myself strange shadows.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Turn you, were I in your case,
I should laugh at mine one shadow.
Who has hired you to make me Coward?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I would make you a good Christian.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Withal, let me continue
An honest man, which I am very certain,
A coward can never be; you take upon you
A Physician's place, rather than a Divines.
You go about to bring my body so low,
I should fight in the Lists tomorrow like a Dormouse,
And be made away in a slumber.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Did you murder Contarino?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: That is a scurvy question now.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Did you ask it as a Confessor, or as a spy?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: As one that fain would jostle the devil
Out of your way.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Vm, you are but weakly made for it:
sp.p:
He is a cunning wrestler, I can tell you, and has broke
many a man's neck.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: But to give him the foil, goes not by strength.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let it go by what it will,
Get me some good victuals to breakfast, I am hungry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Here is food for you.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Pew, I am not to commence Doctor:
For then the word, Devour that book, were proper.
I am to fight, to fight sir, and I will do it,
As I would feed, with a good stomach.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Can you feed, and apprehend death?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why sir? Is not Death
A hungry companion? Say? is not the grave
Said to be a great devourer? Get me some victuals.
I knew a man that was to lose his head,
Feed with an excellent good appetite,
To strengthen his heart, scarce half an hour before.
And if he did it, that only was to speak,
What should I, that am to do?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This confidence,
If it be grounded upon truth, it is well.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: You must understand, that Resolution
Should ever wait upon a noble death,
As Captains bring their Soldiers out of the field,
And come off last: for, I pray what is death?
The safest Trench in the world to keep man free
From Fortunes Gunshot; to be afraid of that,
Would prove me weaker than a teeming woman,
That does endure a thousand times more pain
In bearing of a child.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O, I tremble for you:
For I do know you have a storm within you,
More terrible than a Sea-fight, and your soul
Being heretofore drowned in security,
You know not how to live, nor how to die:
But I have an object that shall startle you,
And make you know whither you are going.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I am armed for it.

stage.p:
Enter Leonora with two Coffins borne by her seruants, and
two Winding-sheets stucke with flowers, presents one to
her sonne, and the other to Iulio.

sp.l: It is very welcome, this is a decent garment
Will never be out of fashion. I will kiss it.
All the Flowers of the Spring,
Meet to perfume our burying:
These have but their growing prime,
And man does flourish but his time.
Survey our progress from our birth,
We are set, we grow, we turn to earth.
Courts adieu, and all delights,
All bewitching appetites;
Sweetest Breath, and clearest eye,
Like perfumes go out and die;
And consequently this is done,
As shadows wait upon the Sun.
Vain the ambition of Kings,
Who seek by trophies and dead things,
To leave a living name behind
And weave but nets to catch the wind:
O you have wrought a miracle, and melted
A heart of Adamant, you have comprised
In this dumb Pageant, a right excellent form
Of penitence.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I am glad you so receive it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: This object does persuade me to forgive
The wrong she has done me, which I count the way
To be forgiven yonder: and this Shroud
Shows me how rankly we do smell of earth,
When we are in all our glory. Will it please you
Enter that Closet, where I shall confer
About matters of most weighty consequence,
Before the Duel.

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: Now I am right in the Bandoleer for the gallows.
What a scurvy fashion it is, to hang ones coffin in a scarf?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why this is well:
And now that I have made you fit for death,
And brought you even as low as is the grave,
I will raise you up again speak comforts to you
Beyond your hopes, turn this intended Duel
To a triumph.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: More Divinity yet?
Good sir, do one thing first, there is in my Closet
A Prayer book that is covered with gilt Vellum,
Fetch it, and pray you certify my mother,
I will presently come to her.
So now you are safe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What have you done?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Why I have locked them up
Into a Turret of the Castle safe enough,
For troubling us this four hours; if he please,
He may open a Casement, and whistle out to the Sea,
Like a Bosun, not any creature can hear him.
Wast not thou a weary of his preaching?

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: Yes, if he had had an hourglass by him,
I would have wished him he would have jogged it a little.
But your mother, your mother is locked in too.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So much the better,
I am rid of her howling at parting.

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: Hark, he knocks to be let out and he were mad.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let him knock till his Sandals fly in pieces.

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: Ha, what says he? Contarino living?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, he means he would have Contarino's living
Bestowed upon his Monastery, it is that
He only fishes for. So, it is break of day,
We shall be called to the combat presently.

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: I am sorry for one thing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: That I made not mine own Ballad: I do fear
I shall be roguishly abused in Meeter,
If I miscarry. Well, if the young Capuchin
Do not talk of the flesh as fast now to your mother,
As he did to us of the spirit; if he do,
It is not the first time that the prison royal
Has been guilty of close committing.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Now to the Combat.

div1.stage: Enter Capuchin and Leonora aboue at a window.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Contarino living?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Yes Madam, he is living, and Ercoles Second.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why has he locked us up thus?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Some evil Angel
Makes him deaf to his own safety, we are shut
Into a Turret, the most desolate prison
Of all the Castle, and his obstinacy,
Madness, or secret fate, has thus pretended,
The saving of his life.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O the saving Contarino's,
His is worth nothing: for heavens sake call louder.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: To little purpose.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will leap these Battlements,
And may I be found dead time enough,
To hinder the combat.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O look upwards rather,
Their deliverance must come thence: to see how heaven,
Can invert man's firmest purpose: his intent
Of murthering Contarino, was a mean
To work his safety, and my coming hither
To save him, is his ruin: wretches turn
The tide of their good fortune, and being drenched
In some presumptuous and hidden sins,
While they aspire to do themselves most right,
The devil that rules in the air, hangs in their light.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
O they must not be lost thus; some good christian
come within our hearing: ope the other casement that
looks into the city.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Madam, I shall.

stage.p:
The Lists set vp. Enter the Marshall, Crispiano, and
Ariosto as Iudges, they sit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Give the Appellant his Summons, do the like
To the Defendant.

stage.p:
Enter at one doore, Ercole and Contarino, at the
other, Romelio and Julio.

sp.l: Can any of you allege aught, why the Combat
Should not proceed?

sp.speaker: Combatants.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Have the Knights weighed.
And measured their weapons?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They have.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Proceed then to the battle, and may heaven
Determine the right.

l.foreign: Soit la battaile, et victoire à ceux qui droit.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Stay, I do not well know whither I am going:
It were needful therefore, though at the last gasp,
To have some Church man's prayer. Run I pray thee,
To Castle Nouo; this key will release
A Capuchin and my mother, whom I shut
Into a Turret, bid them make haste, and pray
I may be dead ere he comes. Now, Victoire à ceux qui ont droit!

l.foreign: Victoire à ceux qui ont droit!

div1.stage: The Combate continued to a good length, when enters Leonora, and the Capuchin.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hold, hold, for heavens sake hold.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What are these that in erupt the combat?
Away to prison with them.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: We have been prisoners too long:
O sir, what mean you? Contarino's living.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: Living!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Behold him living.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: You were but now my second, now I make you
Myself forever.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O here is one between,
Claims to be nearer.

sp.speaker: Cont,
sp.l: And to you dear Lady,
I have entirely vowed my life.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: If I do not dream, I am happy too.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: How insolently has this high Court of Honour
Been abused!

div1.stage: Enter Angiolella vail'd, and Iolenta, her face colour'd like a Moore, the two Surgeons, one of them like a Iew.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: How now, who are these?

sp.speaker: 2. Sur.
sp.l: A couple of strange Foul, and I the Falconer,
That have sprung them. This is a white Nun,
Of the Order of Saint Clare; and this a black one,
You will take my word for it.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: She is a black one indeed.

sp.speaker: Jolen.
sp.l: Like or dislike me, choose you whether,
The Down upon the Raven's feather,
Is a gentle and as sleek,
As the Mole on Venus cheek.
Hence vain show, I only care,
To preserve my Soul most fair.
Never mind the outward skin,
But the Jewel that is within:
And though I want the crimson blood,
Angels boast my Sister-hood.
Which of us now judge you whiter,
Her whose credit proves the lighter,
Or this black, and Ebony hew,
That unstained, keeps fresh and true:
For I reclaim it without control,
There is no true beauty, but in the Soul.

sp.speaker: Erco.
sp.l: O it is the fair Iolenta; to what purpose
Are you thus eclipsed?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.l: Sir, I was running away
From the rumour of this Combat: I fled likewise,
From the untrue report my brother spread
To his politic ends, that I was got with child.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Cease here all further scrutiny, this paper
Shall give unto the Court each circumstance,
Of all these passages.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: No more: attend the Sentence of the Court.
Rareness and difficulty give estimation
To all things are in the world: you have met both
In these several passages: now it does remain,
That these so Comical events be blasted
With no severity of Sentence: You Romelio,
Shall first deliver to that Gentleman,
Who stood your Second, all those Obligations,
Wherein he stands engaged to you,
Receiving only the principal.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iul..
sp.l: I thank you,
I have an humour now to go to Sea
Against the Pirates; and my only ambition,
Is to have my Ship furnished with a rare consort
Of Music; and when I am pleased to be mad,
They shall play me Orlando.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: You must lay wait for the Fiddlers,
They will fly away from the press like Watermen.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Next, you shall marry that Nun.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Angio.
sp.l: O sir, you have been unkind;
But I do only wish, that this my shame,
May warn all honest Virgins, not to seek
The way to Heaven, that is so wondrous steep,
Through those vows they are too frail to keep.

sp.speaker: Ario.
sp.l: Contarino, and Romelio, and yourself,
Shall for seven years maintain against the Turk,
Six Galleys. Leonora, Iolenta,
And Angiolella there the beauteous Nun,
For their vow's breach unto the Monastery,
Shall build a Monastery. Lastly, the two Surgeons,
For concealing Contarino's recovery,
Shall exercise their Art at their own charge,
For a twelve-month in the Galleys: so we leave you,
Wishing your future life may make good use
Of these events, since that these passages,
Which threatened ruin, built on rotten ground,
Are with success beyond our wishes crowned.
